Name: Mexico Pacho Nuevo
Review: ong>Those who enjoy big body and deep, low-toned complexity in a versatile cup.

Name: Sumatra Absynia
Review: ong>Adventurers who enjoy exotic variations on the old-fashioned syrupy, earthy (here pipe-tobaccoish) Sumatra cup.
Coffee Origin: Aceh growing region, northwestern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Bernachon B-039 Roasted Coffee Beans
Review: ong>Crisp, lively straight shot, sweet and delicately complex in milk.

Name: Kenyan Kabare
Review: ong>A brisk but sweet, juicy rendition of the great Kenya profile.

Name: Bernachon B-251 Roasted Coffee Beans
Review: ong>Complex, balanced straight shot with a fine, chocolaty presence in milk.

Name: Monk-Shot Kenyan Kabare (K-Cup compatible)
Review: ong>A very fine, full-flavored rendition of the sweet, berry-toned pungency of a fine Kenya in Keurig-compatible format, although any Keurig owner looking for a breakfast cup with character should enjoy this one. Try to get it fresh.

Name: Bernachon B-886 Roasted Coffee Beans
Review: ong>A paradoxical espresso: chocolaty and sweet in taste but bracing and dry in the mouthfeel.

Name: Ka’u Rusty’s Kenya Style Washed
Review: ong>An exquisitely pure, very light-roasted coffee. Lovers of fine Rieslings and similar fresh, floral-toned white table wines should particularly enjoy this cup.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing district, "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: Mahina Mele Kona
Review: ong>A splendid organically grown Kona that manages to be deep yet delicate, and utterly pure in its peach and floral nuance.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, “Big Island” of Hawaii.

Name: Classic Roast
Review: ong>Elegant and Kenya-like in its intensity and suggestions of pungent berryish fruit and lush flowers.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing district, "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: High Mountain Io Fancy Light Roast
Review: ong>Quiet but lively acidity and a wide range of appealing aromatics – honey, citrus, chocolate, hints of spice and flowers – make this an appealing rendition of the classic Kona cup.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii.

Name: Hawai’i Puna Kazumura
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a lushly deep but delicate cup from a singular and surprising Hawaii origin.

Name: Hawaiian Kona Pau Hana Estate
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a quietly distinguished Kona cup: roundly balanced, not too acidy, grapey, chocolaty.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, “Big Island” of Hawaii.

Name: 100% Kona Fancy
Review: ong>Chocolate and rich flowers should please those who enjoy a Kona cup with gentle acidity and deep-toned, musky aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, “Big Island” of Hawaii.

Name: 100% Waialua Peaberry
Review: ong>Curious aficionados and those who value the quietly exotic. We puzzled over the odd sweet/sour/savory structure of this coffee when we cupped it blind. Such complications can be generated by serendipitous accidents of fruit removal and drying. We hope, however, that they are related to botanical variety, since this sample was produced from trees of a rare and unusual hybrid developed by Hawaii-based scientist Chifumi Nagai that combines the distinctive-tasting Mokka variety, probably originally from Yemen or Ethiopia via Brazil, and a sturdy local strain of the classic Typica.

Name: Haleakala Sunrise
Review: ong>A note to aficionados: This dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” coffee resembles the crisp, cedary dried-in-the-fruit coffees of Brazil more than the sweetly fruity dried-in-the-fruit coffees of Ethiopia and Central America. A quiet, resonant, engaging cup from an unusual origin.

Name: Organic Homacho Waeno Ethiopia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a briskly bright but honeyish sweet cup.
Coffee Origin: Aleta Wondo, Sidama growing region, Ethiopia.

Name: Panama Elida Estate: Washed
Review: ong>A square-on medium roast develops the depth and cedary chocolate of this fine Panama.

Name: Kii Kenya
Review: ong>Kenya balance and contrast – an elegant combination of dry, crisp, almost savory sensations enveloped in sweetness – is impressively on display here.

Name: Harfusa Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>A very pure and accessible rendition of the delicate, precious floral and sweet citrus Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: Kii Kenya Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy espresso in the newer style: sweet but tartly bright, smooth in mouthfeel yet complex and brisk in flavor.

Name: Ethiopia Boke Washed Grade 1
Review: ong>A very exciting coffee, pure but exotic. The subtly layered floral and fruit notes are lyric and original.
Coffee Origin: Boke, Gamo Gofa Zone, Southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Semeon Abay N3
Review: ong>A glorious fruit-bomb of a coffee, juicy, brandyish, unapologetically flamboyant and seductive.

Name: Kenya Kahiriga
Review: ong>A classic Kenya, elegantly dry yet sweetly juicy and chocolate-toned.

Name: Ethiopian Kochere Washed
Review: ong>A balanced, complete structure supports a refreshing, sweetly citrusy aromatic.

Name: Ethiopian Yirgacheffe Aricha
Review: ong>Cautious coffee adventurers. Here the dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” processing produces a soft, complex, rather chocolaty cup free of the fermenty, brandy-like notes often associated with the natural Ethiopia cup.

Name: Ethiopian Medium Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy deeply and complexly expressed acidity, in this case a chorus of sweet, bitter, tart and savory sensations. Not a particularly easy or comfortable coffee, but an exciting one.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ready-to-Drink Coffee Cold Brew
Review: ong>Very refreshing, lively cold-brewed coffee: lilting, lyrical, and organic to boot.

Name: Iced Coffee
Review: ong>An impressively complete and balanced cold coffee, refreshing yet substantial.

Name: Cold Brew
Review: ong>An unusually intense cold coffee, attractively bittersweet in structure and complex and engaging in flavor.

Name: Cold Brewed Coffee Concentrate
Review: ong>Offers the distinctive, pungent fruit typical of fine Central Africa coffees, in this case a Burundi, in cold-brewed coffee format.

Name: Cold Brew Coffee
Review: ong>Crisp and pleasant black, but makes an especially good cold-brewed choice for those who like to add a bit of milk or whitener to their iced cup. Appealing as well to those who prefer to purchase certified organic and/or fair trade products.

Name: Cold Brew Coffee
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a sweetly tart, bracing cold coffee beverage.

Name: Certified Organic Cold Brew Coffee
Review: ong>Those who value the bracing chocolate-toned bittersweetness of darker roasted coffees should enjoy this cold-brewed version of the style.

Name: Cold Brew Coffee
Review: ong>Those who prefer a crisp, gentle, simple but refreshing cold coffee.

Name: Chaquiro Colombia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a naturally sweet, light-roasted coffee that brings a whiff of meadows and morning into the cup.

Name: Elida Estate Panama
Review: ong>Here the round, balanced structure for which Panamas are famous supports an exhilarating display of juicy fruit suggestions, opulent flowers, and a hint of whiskey.

Name: Kenya Baragwi Kagongo Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who enjoy big, intense coffees expressing great range in structure and aromatics, from sweet flowers through complex fruit to savory hints of herb.

Name: Lift Off Espresso
Review: ong>A classic espresso in the newer American style: bright but deep, sweet, complex.
Coffee Origin: Minas Gerais State, Brazil; West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: Costa Rica Helsar Manuel Macho Arce
Review: ong>Those who enjoy grace and subtle originality in a gentle, syrupy cup.
Coffee Origin: West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: El Guamal Colombia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a delicate but sweet and brightly lively breakfast cup.

Name: Sumatra Ulos Batak
Review: ong>A Sumatra both refined and intense; those many lovers of the Sumatra type should not miss this one; purists who still remain suspicious of the type should find this example both familiar (the pungent fruit is almost Kenya-like) yet original: pipe tobacco, clay, richly fudgy chocolate.

Name: Washed Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>A superb Yirgacheffe with emphasis on sweetly tart, complexly expressed fruit notes given depth and crispness by suggestions of cacao nib and spice.
Coffee Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: ong>No grand gestures here, but a remarkably consistent and balanced espresso: delicately chocolaty, a hint of fruit and flowers, full and satiny in mouthfeel, all carrying persuasively into cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Aricha
Review: ong>Classically big, juicy, brandy-toned dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia for those many coffee drinkers who love the style.

Name: Kenya Kikai
Review: ong>Classic Kenya; almost perfectly structured and finely nuanced around sweetly tart fruit and fragrant floral suggestions.

Name: Guatemala ASDECAFE
Review: ong>Those who prefer a gentle but lively and engaging breakfast cup.

Name: Ethiopia Kochere
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a delicately lively, briskly floral- and honey-toned cup.
Coffee Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Rwanda Hinga Kawa
Review: ong>This sweet, deep, floral-toned cup, particularly characteristic of the best Rwandas, should please those who enjoy a pure but exotically complex coffee.

Name: Mexico CESMACH FTO
Review: ong>Those who prefer richness, resonance and chocolate to purity and brightness in a lighter roasted coffee. Good environmental and socio-economic credentials.

Name: Burundi Mpanga
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a very sweet cup deepened by a savory edge.

Name: Mexican Vera Cruz Finca Kassandra
Review: ong>Those who enjoy sweetly dry, slightly savory beverages, in this case complicated by some unusual aromatic intrigue.

Name: Las Margaritas Colombia Gesha
Review: ong>The unusual juxtaposition of brisk, cedary black tea notes with lush ripe fruit and floral sweetness is original and attractive.

Name: El Diamante Huehuetenango Guatemala
Review: ong>Those who enjoy resonant depth and spicy, musky chocolate.
Coffee Origin: Agua Dulce, Huehuetenango growing region, Guatemala.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kore Kochore
Review: ong>A deep, resonant version of the great floral and citrus Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: Sombra del Poro Costa Rica
Review: ong>A relaxed, balanced, straightforward breakfast cup.

Name: SO Espresso Brazil Fazenda Rainha Natural
Review: ong>The intriguingly lush, complex flavor profile should appeal to enthusiasts and casual espresso drinkers alike. This is a forgiving espresso that produces a successful shot at a variety of parameters, making it an attractive choice for beginners.
Coffee Origin: Mogiana Region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Reko
Review: ong>A fine example of the latest style of Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit cup: the fruit delicately lush and clean, the flowers sweet and exhilarating, the whisky-like hint enlivening but discreet.
Coffee Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Summit Premium Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Neither a bright, crisp espresso in the new American style nor a fruit-and-chocolate Italian-style blend; rather, nicely situated between. The persistent floral and ripe citrus notes energize a cedarish chocolate.

Name: Regular Coffee
Review: ong>A balanced, versatile, satisfying cup. And given that shipping is included, a good value.
Coffee Origin: Inza Municipality, Cauca Province, southwestern Colombia.

Name: Organic Colombia El Roble
Review: ong>Those who prefer depth and resonance to brightness and drama in a balanced breakfast cup.

Name: Papua New Guinea
Review: ong>A quiet cup with pleasing aromatics built around grapefruity citrus and a molasses-inflected chocolate. A good choice for those who enjoy a relaxed, accessible, but still original and engaging cup.
Coffee Origin: Wahgi Valley, Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea.

Name: Sulawesi Toarco Jaya
Review: ong>Those who enjoy pungently sweet beverages.
Coffee Origin: Toraja growing region, south-central Sulawesi, Indonesia.

Name: Papua New Guinea Baroida
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a balanced, quietly complex breakfast cup animated by brisk but juicily sweet suggestions of ripe grapefruit.
Coffee Origin: Eastern Highlands Province, Papua New Guinea

Name: Sulawesi Toraja Mamasa
Review: ong>A classic wet-hulled profile of the kind traditionally associated with Sumatra and Sulawesi. Here the famous Indonesia earth notes are crisp and almost graham-cracker-like, rather than lush and humus-like as in some versions of this type. At any rate, a good choice for those who enjoy exploring some of the engaging variations on the Indonesia earth-toned wet-hulled cup.
Coffee Origin: Mamasa growing region, south-central Sulawesi, Indonesia

Name: Papua New Guinea Sihereni
Review: ong>Almost Kenya-like in its sweet, exhilarating acidity and pungent berry suggestions, though approached in any context a fine coffee.
Coffee Origin: Upper Asaro Valley, Eastern Papua New Guinea.

Name: Sulawesi Tana Toraja
Review: ong>A gently bittersweet bite (honey on grapefruit) deepens and grounds the subtle complexities of this silky, quietly original profile.
Coffee Origin: Toraja growing region, South Sulawesi, Indonesia

Name: Sulawesi PT Toarco
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a nicely structured, resonantly balanced cup with quiet, understated aromatic drama.
Coffee Origin: Toraja growing region, southwestern Sulawesi, Indonesia

Name: Papua New Guinea Kunjin
Review: ong>Those who prefer depth and resonance to assertion and brightness in a complex, well-structured cup.
Coffee Origin: Wahgi Valley, Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Ardi
Review: ong>Straightforward structure is lifted by extraordinary aromatic depth and complexity from nose to finish.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Sidama Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ace Espresso
Review: ong>A satisfying espresso with sufficient distinction to excite enthusiasts but round and deep enough to avoid polarizing espresso classicists.

Name: Colombia Piendamo Regional Select
Review: ong>Those to whom an unusual flavor complex, sweet but pungent, deep-toned, slightly spicy, appeals.

Name: Costa Rica Dota
Review: ong>A quiet, sweetly crisp cup with delicate savory hints, the sale of which supports an admirable cause.
Coffee Origin: Santa Maria de Dota valley, Tarrazu growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: Organic Peru Cecovasa
Review: ong>Those who enjoy low acidity and chocolate and nut notes in a certified organically-grown coffee.

Name: Sumatra Lintong
Review: ong>A darker roast develops the chocolate and pungent grapefruit tendencies of this classic wet-hulled Sumatra.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Colombia Agustino Forest
Review: ong>Those who enjoy sweet yet pungently deep and nut-toned profiles.
Coffee Origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia

Name: Kenya Grand Cru
Review: ong>Balance and elegance in a superb classic Kenya.

Name: Celinga Ethiopia Espresso
Review: ong>Definitely not a traditionally rounded, chocolate-and-cedar Italian style espresso, yet deeper, sweeter and considerably more complex than most espressos in the brighter contemporary style.
Coffee Origin: Celinga Village, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Celinga Ethiopia
Review: ong>Simply a superb coffee in the washed southern Ethiopia style, lyric and exhilarating.
Coffee Origin: Celinga Village, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kochere Yirgacheffe Ethiopia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a delicately exotic, crisp yet sweet breakfast cup.

Name: Las Flores Honduras
Review: ong>A strong-structured coffee with a syrupy but dry mouthfeel and pronounced but rounded acidity.

Name: Brazil Serra Do Bone
Review: ong>Those who prefer forests to meadows, poetic dusk to bright mornings.
Coffee Origin: Matas de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Brazil Araponga Temple Select
Review: ong>A good candidate for those who avoid brightly acidy coffees and prefer balance and subtle layered complexity to assertion and intensity.

Name: Rwanda Gashonga
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a sweetly pungent cup with just a hint of savory depth.

Name: Kiawamururu Kenya
Review: ong>Pure, delicate, gently bright; a meadow in a cup.

Name: Doyo Coop Ethiopia
Review: ong>A tactful light roast allows the honey-toned sweetness to dominate in this very pure, delicate coffee.
Coffee Origin: Jimma Zone, Oromia Region, southwestern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Levelup Coffee Natural
Review: ong>A fine example of the latest style of dried-in-the-fruit or natural coffees, in which the fruit notes are pungently crisp rather than lushly fermenty.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Shakiso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a refreshing, brisk yet juicy coffee with a gently exotic fruit and floral character.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidama Province, Ethiopia.

Name: Gatomboya Bourbon SL28 Kenya
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the sweetly tart, dry berry and lush floral character of a fine Kenya.

Name: Colombia Santiago Joven
Review: ong>A distinctive variation on the classic Colombia profile, juicy with a crisp, engaging savory edge.
Coffee Origin: Timana growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia

Name: Ethiopia Ardi
Review: ong>Those who enjoy gentle complexity and balance and a bit of savory/cidery intrigue.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Sidama Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Tanzania Shiwanda Estate Peaberry
Review: ong>Quietly complete cup with a slight spice hint to the flowers. Expresses the combination of delicacy and sensory depth traditionally associated with the Tanzania peaberry, a classic coffee type particularly prominent in the early decades of the North American specialty coffee movement.

Name: Congo Muungano
Review: ong>The agave- and tangerine-like notes in particular animate this sweetly tart, complex cup.
Coffee Origin: Kalehe, Southern Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo.

Name: Burundi Kayanza Gitika
Review: ong>Those who enjoy coffees sweet and pure enough to achieve completeness in a very light roasting style.

Name: Flor Del Huila
Review: ong>Understated but bright, a subtle Colombia for subtle classicists.
Coffee Origin: Garzon growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia.

Name: Tanzania Nyoni
Review: ong>Chocolate and flowers – sounds right for spring.
Coffee Origin: Matengo Highlands, Ruvuma Region, southwestern Tanzania.

Name: Copan Honduras
Review: ong>A calm though resonant coffee for calm though resonant mornings.

Name: Ethiopia Danch Meng
Review: ong>A fine example of the new style of Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit coffee, with the lush fruit and chocolate notes characteristic of the processing method, yet still pure, classic, complete.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Bokasso Coop
Review: ong>A quietly crisp version of the southern Ethiopia cup, with the floral, citrus and cacao notes expressed with classic subtlety.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Bali Kintamani
Review: ong>Lovers of the flamboyantly fruit-and-spirits style of dried-in-the-fruit coffee, intoxicating and complex, dusk in a tropical forest. Not for coffee purists.

Name: Rwanda Bufcafe
Review: ong>A hint of the elegant dry berry character animating Kenya coffee complicates this deeper, more chocolaty version of the Kenya coffee idea.

Name: Rwanda Karongi Gitesi
Review: ong>Complete in structure and exotic in detail: honey and spice in a lush, syrupy-bodied cup.

Name: Rwanda Gitesi
Review: ong>Unusual and attractive profile, with a bracing grapefruity brightness enveloped in honey and flowers.

Name: Rwanda Lake Kivu Kabirizi FTO
Review: ong>Rounded power in a juicy, big-bodied cup with subtly original aromatics.

Name: Rwanda Karongi Gitesi
Review: ong>Those who enjoy their chocolate with complications, both savory and floral.

Name: Rwanda Cotecaga Bourbon
Review: ong>Those who enjoy big-bodied, richly acidy coffees with resonantly original aromatics, grapey and complexly floral.

Name: Rwanda Kirezi
Review: ong>Lovers of originality, in this case driven by paradox: crisply savory nut enveloped in honey-and-floral sweetness.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Tambaya AA
Review: ong>Deep, ringing version of the celebrated Kenya profile, distinguished in particular by intense dry berry and savory-sweet floral notes.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Ardi Natural
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the lush blueberry-and-brandy style of southern Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit coffees. A fine, complexly expressed version of the type.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirga Natural Bedhatu
Review: ong>Brisk but lush profile for those who enjoy both balance and excitement.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Moplaco Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>Bittersweet citrus and delicate florals make this juicy, lively profile a distinctive variation on the great washed Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: Rwanda Kabirizi Washing Station
Review: ong>Those who prefer resonant sweetness and gentle complexity in a versatile, all-day cup.

Name: Guji Zone Ethiopia
Review: ong>Lovers of grand sensory gestures; Cirque du Soleil in a cup.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidama Province, Ethiopia.

Name: Keynote Perennial Brew
Review: ong>Comfort without compromise: a round, drinkable coffee with soft but lively acidity and impressive complexity.
Coffee Origin: Sul de Minas growing region, southern Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Colombia El Bado
Review: ong>Fine balance in a roundly tart but very sweet profile.

Name: Colombian Monserrate B
Review: ong>The deep, resonant sweetness of night-blooming flowers in particular permeates this soft, melodic coffee.

Name: Colombia Tolima La Aldea
Review: ong>Those who value poise and balance in a delicately structured, sweetly fragrant cup.

Name: Colombia Finca Santa Maria Caturra
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the big, rich style of Colombia cup, with the chocolaty sweetness balanced by a crisp cedary edge.

Name: Organic Colombia Fondo Paez Cooperative
Review: ong>Classic Colombia breakfast cup with bonus nuance and depth and a fine social and environmental story.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Colombia Huila Million Pesos Natural
Review: ong>Fine and original variant on the dried-in-the-fruit cup, preserving the pungent, complex sweetness of the type with little of the usual fermenty fruit.

Name: Colombia San Agustin
Review: ong>Those who enjoy quiet distinction, depth and resonance in a versatile, all-day cup.
Coffee Origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia

Name: Colombia Finca Monte Verde, Gildardo Gutierrez
Review: ong>A contemplative coffee with a savory-sweet complexity that rewards attentiveness.

Name: Colombia Cerro Azul Enano
Review: ong>An extraordinary bargain: offers a persuasive version of the sensory fireworks of a great Gesha at about one-fifth the price.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Colombia Cerro Azul Geisha
Review: ong>If a coffee ever merited the term elegant, this one does. Delicately but perfectly structured, with an amazingly consistent and original aroma-flavor complex.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Rwanda Kabirizi FTO
Review: ong>A gentle but distinctively engaging breakfast cup with Fair Trade and organic credentials.

Name: Twisted 3.0 Espresso
Review: ong>As a straight shot complex and satisfying; sweet and flavor-nuanced in cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Bufcafe Rwanda Espresso
Review: ong>Balanced, versatile espresso with a low-toned, resonant complexity in both straight shot and cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Rock the House Blend FTO
Review: ong>Delicate but sweetly and crisply engaging breakfast cup with impressive social and environmental credentials.

Name: Ethiopia Amaro Gayo Dry Process
Review: ong>Cacao-nib crisp but amaretto-like sweet, resonantly complex, a superb version of the dried-in-the-fruit southern Ethiopia type.

Name: El Salvador Las Delicias Natural
Review: ong>A hint of clean ferment contributes a whisky-like shimmer to the complex fruit and floral notes of this impressive dried-in-the-fruit coffee.

Name: Kenya Kikai
Review: ong>A fine variation on the sweet and berryish yet crisply dry-boned Kenya profile.

Name: Easter Sunrise Blend
Review: ong>Crisp delicacy and vanilla and floral tones that could add up to lily may make this breakfast blend particularly suitable for Easter-time spring mornings.

Name: Monk-Shot Kenya Kikai (K-Cup compatible)
Review: ong>Manages to carry some of the crisply berry-toned distinction of a fine Kenya into the generally muting K-cup format, but Kenya aside, any Keurig owner looking for a sweet, berry-and-floral-toned breakfast cup should enjoy this one.

Name: Monk-Shot Easter Sunrise Blend (K-Cup compatible)
Review: ong>Low-toned but complex, gently brisk all-day cup for Keurig owners.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo
Review: ong>Solid structure and deep, exotic aromatics should both reassure and surprise at breakfast.

Name: Ethiopia Gedeo Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>An extravagant yet crisply focused coffee; a fine morning surprise.

Name: Java Taman Dadar
Review: ong>Those who know and enjoy Sumatra coffees should particularly enjoy this moderately dark-roasted, briskly complex variation on the Indonesian wet-hulled cup.

Name: Blue Sky Breakfast Blend
Review: ong>Sweet chocolate and floral notes are deepened by pungent pineapple and aromatic wood in this gently complex, balanced breakfast cup.

Name: Whidbey Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a pungently intense, nicely nuanced bittersweet chocolate character in small cup and short milk.

Name: Brazil Yellow Catuai Esperança Joao “Zinho” Souza
Review: ong>Those who value delicacy without loss of complexity.
Coffee Origin: Cerrado growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Brazil Fazenda Furnas Natural
Review: ong>Definitely not purists; rather those who enjoy the lush, edgily overripe fruit and floral sweetness of an old-fashioned dried-in-the-fruit coffee.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Brazil Fazenda Sertaozinho
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a measure of tart authority in a crisp, cacao-toned Brazil.
Coffee Origin: Sao Sebastiao da Grama, Sao Paulo state, south-central Brazil.

Name: Brazil Pedra Redonda
Review: ong>Those who enjoy spicy flowers and near-incense-like pungency, softened by a more familiar chocolaty cacao-nib note.
Coffee Origin: Matas de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Brasil Carmo De Minas Fazenda Monte Verde Bourbon
Review: ong>Some may find the bittersweet acidity bracing, others mildly distracting, but everyone should enjoy deep, complex aromatics, particularly as they stretch far into a resonant finish.
Coffee Origin: Mantiqeiras de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Brazil Yellow Bourbon Laranjal Farms
Review: ong>This refined, delicate version of the classic Brazil dried-in-the-fruit profile may particularly please those who find brighter, higher-grown coffees too assertive but who still crave some aromatic intrigue. The rose-like notes are rich and impressive.
Coffee Origin: Pocos de Caldas, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Brazil Grota Funda
Review: ong>Lovers of subtle dessert-like flavors in coffee.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Brazil Bela Vista Micro-Lot
Review: ong>Those who enjoy balance and subtle, layered complexity. The chocolate note is particularly pure and delicate.
Coffee Origin: Dom Vicoso, Minas Gerais state, east-central Brazil.

Name: Brazil Leuven Santa Margarida Estate Lot 129
Review: ong>The soft acidity of a classic Brazil combined with authority in structure and engaging aroma and flavor. When it is next available, aficionados will definitely want to sample this coffee to tease out the sensory impact of adding wine yeast to the vat during the fermentation step, as well as to experience what in our records is the lightest roasted coffee ever tested at Coffee Review, certainly the only one close to this light to score so well.

Name: Rwanda Karongi Gitesi
Review: ong>The sweet sage note in particular deepens and adds nuance to this fine, deeply-expressed version of the Bourbon-influenced Central Africa cup.

Name: Gelgelu Adame Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Organic Natural Process
Review: ong>A dried-in-the-fruit Yirgacheffe for purists: cleanly and grandly opulent.

Name: Taiwan Alishan Washed Sumatra Typica
Review: ong>A coffee both elegant and exotic from a still rare origin. Taiwan readers in particular may want to buy it to support the home team.

Name: Regular Coffee
Review: ong>Those who enjoy an aromatically straightforward though roundly big-bodied cup at an affordable price.

Name: Cocoa Sweet Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a versatile espresso with impressive depth and low-toned, savory-sweet complexity.

Name: Regular Coffee Decaf
Review: ong>The impact of decaffeination drains aromatics from this solid, good-value coffee, but leaves a pleasingly full, syrupy mouthfeel and a fresh, woody sweetness.

Name: Sulawesi Tana Toraja Peaberry
Review: ong>An unusual overlap of ripe, slightly savory tomato and sweet, vanilla-like flowers animates this distinctive coffee.
Coffee Origin: Toraja growing region, South Sulawesi, Indonesia

Name: Ecuador Finca La Nube
Review: ong>Clean, delicate vivacity should please any coffee drinker, but aficionados may be particularly interested in sampling a coffee produced in Latin America from a distinctive coffee variety closely associated with East Africa.

Name: Colombia Huila
Review: ong>A classic Colombia in the traditional style: bright but sweet and balanced; complete without flourishes or drama. Classic breakfast-cup drinkers should enjoy it.

Name: Guatemala Guaya’B Huehuetenango
Review: ong>Round, low-toned coffee that rewards patient drinking with an oaky, chocolaty depth.

Name: Ethiopia FTO Worka
Review: ong>Those interested in a cleanly expressed yet triumphantly intricate example of the dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” Ethiopia profile. Extraordinary value for the money.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Testa Rossa Classic Espresso Blend
Review: ong>This bold-charactered espresso makes a hearty straight shot and contributes to a smooth, roundly chocolaty caffè latte.

Name: Aricha Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural Process
Review: ong>Those who enjoy coffees that insist on being noticed.

Name: Kenya Makwa AB
Review: ong>Extraordinary coffee with the always astounding Kenya fusion of big, berry-toned sweetness with crisp, dry authority and aromatic depth and complexity.

Name: Kabirizi Rwanda
Review: ong>Those who enjoy syrupy mouthfeel and resonant, low-toned complexity.

Name: Wahana Sumatra
Review: ong>Coffee adventurers looking for quiet excitement. Unusual aroma and flavor, lush but crisp, cidery.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Tolima Colombia
Review: ong>Try it for the distinct toffee-like character haloed by a rather deep, sweet floral note and pungent fir.

Name: Palanda Ecuador Organic
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a quietly lively cup from a relatively rare origin.

Name: Kenya Kabare AB
Review: ong>Very sweet but superbly balanced structure and deep, engaging aromatics should please nearly everyone.

Name: Sumatra Wahana Natural Process
Review: ong>Those who enjoy refreshingly clean, whisky-toned fruit in the more balanced style of dried-in-the-fruit cup.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Peaberry Reserve
Review: ong>Those who enjoy white wines that that are both crisply dry and delicately and sweetly floral.

Name: Honduras Santa Barbara Beneficio San Vicente Caracolillo
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a classic but distinctive breakfast cup, zesty yet plush.

Name: Ferghana Horse Blend
Review: ong>Straight espresso aficionados who enjoy resonant, sweet-toned flavor in their shots will particularly appreciate this versatile blend’s balance and range.

Name: Kenya Makwa AB
Review: ong>Classic Kenya. Balanced in structure but with the Kenya aroma/flavor complex on steroids. If you don’t know Kenyas, try this one. If you do know Kenyas and you like them, don’t miss this one. Spectacular.

Name: Monk-Shot Tanzanian Peaberry (K-Cup compatible)
Review: ong>A crisp, balanced cup for Keurig owners, nut- and chocolate-toned.

Name: Grade 1 Espresso Blend
Review: ong>A versatile espresso. Hearty and strong-charactered as a straight shot; rounds and sweetens but remains lively in milk.

Name: El Salvador Santa Elena Honey Pacamara
Review: ong>A classically bright cup enveloped in sweetness and heady aromatics. A breakfast cup with a major aromatic bonus.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe ECX Auction Lot
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the natural sweetness and exhilarating citrus and flowers of a classic Yirgacheffe.

Name: Guatemala El Diamante Patricia Diaz Microlot
Review: ong>Those who prefer resonance and layered complexity to bright intensity.
Coffee Origin: San Pedro Necta, Huehuetenango growing region, Guatemala.

Name: Farm Girl
Review: ong>Lovers of light, dry white table wines.

Name: Apex Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a honey-toned, complexly refreshing morning cup.

Name: Lake Effect
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a sweetly brisk, citrusy morning cup.

Name: Gingerbread Man Seasonal Espresso (reviewed for drip applications)
Review: ong>Those who prefer quiet, sweet-toned resonance to bright assertion.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Ethiopia; Toraja growing region, Sulawesi, Indonesia; Costa Rica.

Name: Gamut Espresso (reviewed for drip applications)
Review: ong>Those many coffee drinkers who enjoy a round, gently complex, sweetly chocolaty cup.

Name: Dream Blend
Review: ong>A tribute to the blender’s art: delicately refined structure supports a quietly distinctive, layered complexity.

Name: Fragrance of Tranquility
Review: ong>A very comprehensive cup: well-structured, crisply sweet, with a wide range of aromatic intrigue.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; Kenya; Mandheling growing region of Sumatra, Indonesia; other undisclosed origins.

Name: Rite of Spring
Review: ong>Lovers of bright, aromatic spring mornings.

Name: Ganesha Espresso (reviewed for drip applications)
Review: ong>Those who prefer depth and complex chocolaty sweetness to the brighter, brisker, cleaner pleasures of many third-wave drip coffees.

Name: Est Drip Blend
Review: ong>Tribute both to the distinctive quality of the component coffees and the blender’s art: Clearly articulated but intricate structure, broad-ranging aromatics. No single-origin coffee I know of offers quite the same package.
Coffee Origin: Ethiopia; Costa Rica; Papua New Guinea.

Name: Three Africans
Review: ong>Distinctive but versatile blend (pleasing with whitener or without) with a wide stance: simultaneously displays a lemony brightness, blueberry and chocolate sweetness, and a savory musk.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe and Sidamo (also Sidama) growing regions, southern Ethiopia; Uganda.

Name: Espresso Blend Spring 14
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a drying but very complex and densely textured straight shot; rounds and sweetens pleasingly in short milk.

Name: Peru Cajamarca
Review: ong>Those who enjoy balance, delicacy and subtle complexity in a classic American-style breakfast cup.

Name: Organic Bali Kintamani Natural
Review: ong>Adventurers with a sweet tooth.

Name: Kenya Kalilani
Review: ong>Those who enjoy depth and resonance in a cup that complicates seductive sweetness with a savory pungency.

Name: Ethiopian Sidamo Kellenso
Review: ong>A crisply (and skillfully) light-roasted version of the fruit-and-brandy style of southern Ethiopia natural-processed cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Ninety Plus Pheribo N2
Review: ong>Striking coffee, both in the balance, sweetness and completeness of its structure as well as in its exhilarating range of sensory suggestion.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya Ndaroini Nyeri
Review: ong>Those who enjoy gently bracing, sweet-toned acidity in beverages, as displayed in certain dry white table wines, for example. This sensation is elegantly and complexly expressed here.

Name: Ethiopia Zonegediyo Kochere Yirga Cheffe
Review: ong>An unusually deep and resonantly authoritative version of the Yirgacheffe cup; the flowers are still there, but they show an almost carnal richness.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Sidama Shilcho Coop G1
Review: ong>Those who prefer their coffees gentle but exhilaratingly complex.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Sumatra Lake Tawar Screen 19 Plus TP
Review: ong>Those who appreciate a richly pungent though refined version of the classic Sumatra profile.
Coffee Origin: Aceh growing region, northwestern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Big Papua Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a richly bright, lively straight shot or a chocolaty but still gently citrusy cappuccino.
Coffee Origin: Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea; Huehuetenango, Guatemala.

Name: Caffe Primo
Review: ong>A big-bodied, dry but chocolaty straight shot espresso with enough presence to stand up to tall milk and syrups.
